results.title: A Year to Remember 1953
results.brief_description: Collection of newsreel footage which made up Australia’s history in 1953 - Deaths of Stalin and Queen Mary - Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II - US Vice President Nixon visits Australia - Testing of the Jindivik at Woomera - Mt Everest conquered by Sir Edmund Hillary and Tensing - Anzac Day in Korea - Exchange of POW’s - Express train crash in New Zealand - Davis Cup wins by Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall - Ben Hogan wins British Open … and much more. Rated: G

results.title: US Navy Ciné-Kodak Special
results.brief_description: Eastman Kodak introduced the Ciné-Kodak Special in 1933. The silent 16mm camera was durable and lightweight enough to be used by combat photographers working in the field and Kodak manufactured a military version in all-black without the usual chrome edges.

constellations_primary.name: Australia and WW2
constellations_primary.description: A constellation exploring representations of Australians during World War 2.

results.description: Footage captured during war has the ability to give audiences a sense of what is happening in combat, documenting the frontlines with an unflinching lens and bearing witness to atrocities. Yet it can also be used as propaganda to enlist forces, making it a powerful tool. Eastman Kodak introduced the Ciné-Kodak Special in 1933 following on from its earlier model the Ciné-Kodak in 1923. The silent 16mm camera was durable and lightweight enough to be used by combat photographers working in the field and Kodak manufactured a military version in all-black without the usual chrome edges.
description_for_label: Footage captured during war has the ability to give audiences a sense of what is happening in combat, documenting the frontlines with an unflinching lens and bearing witness to atrocities. Yet it can also be used as propaganda to enlist forces, making it a powerful tool. Eastman Kodak introduced the Ciné-Kodak Special in 1933 following on from its earlier model the Ciné-Kodak in 1923. The silent 16mm camera was durable and lightweight enough to be used by combat photographers working in the field and Kodak manufactured a military version in all-black without the usual chrome edges.

results.title: Thomas Alva Edison
results.brief_description: After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Thomas Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats.

constellations_primary.name: Thomas Edison
constellations_primary.description: Thomas Edison helped establish cinema as an art-form and mass entertainment. Many of his early films were short and showed everyday activities like riding a bicycle.

results.description: Thomas Edison daydreamed at school. Though his teachers were unimpressed, the American inventor later imagined numerous innovative devices and processes. He improved the telegraph system and created the first commercially practical light bulb, as well as the phonograph sound recorder. After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats. One film was Fred Ott’s Sneeze (1894), which, like many of the films, Dickson produced with another Edison invention, the Kinetograph, the first motion-picture camera. These inventions contributed to filmmaking as we know it – and prove it pays to daydream.
description_for_label: Thomas Edison daydreamed at school. Though his teachers were unimpressed, the American inventor later imagined numerous innovative devices and processes. He improved the telegraph system and created the first commercially practical light bulb, as well as the phonograph sound recorder. After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats. One film was Fred Ott’s Sneeze (1894), which, like many of the films, Dickson produced with another Edison invention, the Kinetograph, the first motion-picture camera. These inventions contributed to filmmaking as we know it – and prove it pays to daydream.

results.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides
results.brief_description: The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them before staging performances like The Blind Man of Siloam.

constellations_primary.name: Religion, cinema and censorship
constellations_primary.description: Religious narratives and themes have a complicated relationship with censorship, with creators pushing the boundaries for better or worse.

results.description: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.
description_for_label: The Salvation Army isn’t just a part of Melbourne’s social fabric – it’s also an integral part of moving-image history. The Salvation Army ran Australia’s first production company, The Limelight Department. They produced hundreds of scenes and stories by photographing actors in elaborate sets and costumes, printing these scenes on slides and then hand-colouring them in the department’s Bourke Street studio. The Blind Man of Siloam shows how this technique re-created ancient locations from hand-painted backgrounds. The department’s most famous show, Soldiers of the Cross, featured over 200 slides projected from multiple lanterns, as well as hymns, music, motion-picture segments and rousing narration.

results.title: Sergei Eisenstein
results.brief_description: Sergei Eisenstein was a Soviet director and film theorist who pioneered the use of montage and changed how we see cinema. Eisenstein believed that juxtaposing different film shots created meaning, manipulated emotions and communicated ideas through visual metaphors.

constellations_primary.name: Auteurs, influence and inspiration
constellations_primary.description: A tradition of influence and inspiration beginning with Eisenstein.

results.description: Sergei Eisenstein was a Soviet director and film theorist who pioneered the use of montage and changed how we see cinema. Eisenstein believed that juxtaposing different film shots created meaning, manipulated emotions and communicated ideas through visual metaphors. By the time he released his second film, Battleship Potemkin (1925), he’d put the theory into practice: he assembled over 1,300 shots in an 82-minute film to tell the story of a shipboard mutiny, propelling the action through his new cinematic technique. Montage was unlike anything seen before and influenced not just directors like Alfred Hitchcock, Brian De Palma and Martin Scorsese but also the rapidly edited style of advertising and music videos.
description_for_label: Sergei Eisenstein was a Soviet director and film theorist who pioneered the use of montage and changed how we see cinema. Eisenstein believed that juxtaposing different film shots created meaning, manipulated emotions and communicated ideas through visual metaphors. By the time he released his second film, Battleship Potemkin (1925), he’d put the theory into practice: he assembled over 1,300 shots in an 82-minute film to tell the story of a shipboard mutiny, propelling the action through his new cinematic technique. Montage was unlike anything seen before and influenced not just directors like Alfred Hitchcock, Brian De Palma and Martin Scorsese but also the rapidly edited style of advertising and music videos.

results.title: Paulette McDonagh on the set of The Cheaters
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Filmmaking was a family affair for writer and director Paulette McDonagh. During the 1920s and 30s in Sydney, McDonagh worked with her sisters Isabel and Phyllis to make some of the most acclaimed silent Australian films.

constellations_primary.name: Voice and the moving image
constellations_primary.description: Sound changed cinema, but it wasn't always welcome, but it hasn't stopped people aspiring for the spotlight.

results.title_for_label: Paulette McDonagh on the set of The Cheaters
results.description:
Filmmaking was a family affair for writer and director Paulette McDonagh. During the 1920s and 30s in Sydney, McDonagh worked with her sisters Isabel and Phyllis to make some of the most acclaimed silent Australian films. Their first film, Those Who Love (1926), was funded by their family and hailed as a “dazzling triumph” by publication Everyone’s.

Influenced by Hollywood melodramas and German Expressionism, the sisters’ films featured emotionally honest characters and broke with traditional gender norms. Fox Films even offered McDonagh and her sisters the chance to make movies in Hollywood, but they decided they “would end up very small fish in a big pond” so stayed in Australia, where they worked up until the mid-1930s.
description_for_label:
Filmmaking was a family affair for writer and director Paulette McDonagh. During the 1920s and 30s in Sydney, McDonagh worked with her sisters Isabel and Phyllis to make some of the most acclaimed silent Australian films. Their first film, Those Who Love (1926), was funded by their family and hailed as a “dazzling triumph” by publication Everyone’s.

Influenced by Hollywood melodramas and German Expressionism, the sisters’ films featured emotionally honest characters and broke with traditional gender norms. Fox Films even offered McDonagh and her sisters the chance to make movies in Hollywood, but they decided they “would end up very small fish in a big pond” so stayed in Australia, where they worked up until the mid-1930s.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.

results.title: Natalie Kalmus
results.brief_description: When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939).

constellations_primary.name: Communicating colour
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of colour on-screen inspired by Technicolor supervisor, Natalie Kalmus.

results.description:
When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939) and Gone with the Wind (1939).

After seeing filmmakers use the earlier two-strip Technicolor process to produce “unnatural and disastrous results”, she urged filmmakers to employ “colour restraint”. Kalmus believed that colour theories used in paintings could also be used in film and encouraged filmmakers to carefully consider which colours would convey a story’s emotions and themes.
description_for_label:
When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939) and Gone with the Wind (1939).

After seeing filmmakers use the earlier two-strip Technicolor process to produce “unnatural and disastrous results”, she urged filmmakers to employ “colour restraint”. Kalmus believed that colour theories used in paintings could also be used in film and encouraged filmmakers to carefully consider which colours would convey a story’s emotions and themes.
